passage.text: (1) Images of nature have accompanied people from the most ancient times. (2) The ancient people left us as a legacy of hunting scenes on the walls of caves, on stones in the form of scanty scratches, depicting moose, wild boars, and rounds. (3) Current technology makes it possible to see animals and birds in natural colors and settings. (4) We see episodes of their lives, and a warm feeling appears in the soul. (5) They are somewhere, these animals, they are still running, growling, hiding or showing, like us humans, curiosity ... (6) Wanting to experience this warm feeling, we keep cats, dogs, parrots on city floors, squirrels, fish in the aquarium. (7) Doctors say that stroking a cat or feeding a tit from the palm is healing for the human psyche. (8) A hare I met in the park corrected my mood. (9) And how many cases when a person is connected with life only by a thread of communication with a dog, with ordinary sparrows or crows! (10) A former employee of our editorial office from time to time on the phone reports to me about the life of crows in the yard, that they love to eat, as they unmistakably recognize it among the mass of people. (11) And the old woman in our yard every morning carries crumbs to the sparrows. (12) And I see joy on the face of a woman watching as fussy birds pick up the scattered food. (13) Sometimes it seems to me: the sparrows will not fly to her exit from the entrance, and the old woman will die from the breakage of the last thread connecting her with life. (14) Once we got into a conversation with her, and she confessed that she had never seen in her life how the cranes fly by and cry. (15) I told her how cranes dance in the spring, breaking into pairs, and shout so that their voices merge into one triumphant sound of love. (16) The old woman listened attentively and, saying goodbye, said three words: "How happy you are ..." (17) The Yasnaya Polyana sage said the same thing in his diaries: "Happiness is being with nature, seeing it, talking to it." (According to V.M. Peskov)

passage.text: (1) One thing is clear to me: the main participants in history are People and Time.(2) Do not forget Time means not forgetting People, not forgetting People means not forgetting Time.(3) The number of divisions that participated in this or in another battle, historians calculate with scrupulous accuracy.(4) However, they will not be able to overhear a conversation in a trench before a tank attack, to see the suffering and tears in the eyes of an eighteen-year-old girl-sanitary instructor dying in the darkness of a dilapidated dugout, around which the bursting German tanks are buzzing, to feel the crack a machine-gun burst that kills life.(5) We were then twenty years old.(6) We dreamed of returning to that sunny pre-war world where the sun seemed to us a festive sun rising above the earth from day to day according to its immutable pattern; the herb was a herb meant to grow; lanterns - in order to illuminate the dry April sidewalk, the evening crowd of walking, in which you are walking too, eighteen, tanned, strong.(7) All the showers merrily passed over your head, and you were mischievously glad to the glint of lightning and cannon rolls of thunder; all the smiles in that time were intended for you, all deaths and tears were strangers ... (8) The whole world, transparently radiant, lay at your feet in early blue April, warming with kindness, joy, waiting for love.(9) There, behind, there was no fierce intransigence, everywhere there was a greenish-light watercolor in the air; and there were no harsh black paints.(10) For the long four years of war, feeling the fiery breath of death near our shoulder, silently passing by fresh bumps with chemical pencil inscriptions on the tablets, we did not lose the old world of youth in ourselves, but we grew up twenty years and, it seemed, lived them in such detail, so richly that these years would be enough for the life of two generations.(11) We learned that the world is both strong and unsteady.(12) We learned that the sun may not rise in the morning, because its brilliance, its warmth can be destroyed by bombing when the horizon sinks in a black-purple curtain of smoke.(13) ) Sometimes we hated the sun - it promised flying weather and, therefore, shoals of Junkers diving into the trenches.(14) We learned that the sun can tenderly warm not only in summer, but also in the most severe January frosts, at the same time indifferent and merciless to reveal with its light in all details the recent picture of the battle, torn apart by direct hits from guns, the bodies of the dead, whom you called by name a minute ago.(15) We recognized the world together with human courage and suffering.(16) Time has already touched our memory: details have faded, the half-forgotten faces of the dead, the smells of trenches torn apart by shells are not so acutely perceptible in the memories, you do not instinctively bend down on the street at the distant sound of a jackhammer, reminiscent of the fight of a large-caliber machine gun.(17) mov does not burst from the throat of an involuntary cry: "Lie down!"(18) As usual, you do not look for a place on the corner, near a pharmacy or a department store (a place for a firing position with a wide firing sector), and a child's cry, accidentally heard in the twilight, does not recall the black outlines of broken villages, stove fumes of smoking ruins, charred gardens , crying in the dark.(19) The long-awaited peace (we walked to it for four years) firmly entered our consciousness - a world with the glitter of the morning sun on the pavements, with the rustle of overcrowded trolleybuses in the evenings and a cozy ride of doves on the cornices at dawn.(According to Yu.Bondarev *)

(3) There are three kinds of love: beautiful love, selfless love and active love. (4) I'm talking about love for a person, which, depending on the greater or lesser strength of the soul, focuses on one thing, on some or poured out on many. (7) People who loving t with beautiful love, they care very little about reciprocity as a circumstance that has no effect on the beauty and pleasantness of feeling. (8) They often change the objects of their love, since their main goal is only to make the pleasant feeling of love constantly aroused (9) In order to maintain this pleasant feeling in themselves, they constantly speak in the most graceful expressions about their love both for the object itself and for all those who do not even care about this love. (10) For people who they love so much, the beloved object is so kind as it excites that pleasant feeling, the consciousness and expression of which they enjoy.(11) The second kind of love is selfless love, it consists in love for the process of sacrificing oneself for a beloved object, while not paying attention to whether these sacrifices are worse or better for the beloved object. (12) People who love this way never believe reciprocity. passage.text: (1) Injustice has been spoken and written about since ancient times - perhaps since the time when humanity in general learned to speak and write. (2) What is injustice is still not clear. (3) It is very difficult to come to an agreement on this issue, since in this case the dispute is being conducted with a sufficient share of interest. (4) Everyone wants to be treated “justly” and complains about “injustice,” but tries to interpret the situation in such a way that the injustice is immediately apparent. (5) And everyone has enough self-importance to judge "justly" about the attitude towards other people, and does not at all notice that others are indignant at his supposed "justice." (6) So the problem is distorted by passions and shrouded in prejudice. (7) Whole generations get stuck in these prejudices, and sometimes you notice how the very word "justice" evokes a sarcastic smile. (8) From previous generations, mankind inherited the belief that people are equal from birth and, therefore, must be treated in the same way. (9) However, the essence of justice consists precisely in the unequal treatment of unequal people. (10) If people were truly equal, life would be extremely simple and justice would be extremely easy to find. (11) It would only be worthwhile to say: to the same people - the same share, or to all equally. (12) Then justice could be justified arithmetically and created mechanically; and everyone would be happy, because people would become nothing more than identical atoms, a kind of rolling mechanical balls everywhere, which would be similar externally and would have internally the same mental makeup. (13) How naive, how simple, how petty! (14) In fact, people are not equal in body, soul or spirit. (15) They will be born as creatures of different sexes, with different health and strength, with completely different predispositions, gifts, instincts and desires, they belong to a different spiritual level, and with them (by virtue of justice!) (16) This is the basis and the main difficulty of justice: there are an infinite number of people; they are all different; how to make everyone receive according to justice? (17) If people are not the same, then it is necessary to treat them every time according to their living originality - otherwise injustice arises. (18) Thus, justice means precisely inequality: to take care of the child, to help the weak, to condescend to the tired, to look after the sick; show more severity towards the weak-willed, more trust in the honest, more caution towards the chatterbox; honor the hero. (19) Justice is therefore the art of inequality, and it is inherent only in noble souls. (20) She has a heightened sense of reality; stemming from a kind heart and lively observation, it rejects a mechanical approach to people, tries to capture in a person his essence and originality and treat him accordingly. (According to I. Ilyin *)

passage.text: (1) Tick tock, tick tock! (2) At night, in silence and loneliness, it is terrifying to listen to the impassive eloquence of the pendulum of the clock: the sounds are monotonous and mathematically correct, consistently marking always the same thing - the tireless movement of life. (3) Darkness and sleep envelop the earth, everything is silent - only the clock coldly and loudly marks the disappearance of the seconds ... (4) The pendulum knocks, and with each sound life is reduced by a second, by a tiny fraction of time given to each of us, by a second that will not return to us. (5) Where do the seconds come from and where do they disappear? (6) No one will answer this ... (7) And there are still many questions that have not been answered, there are other, more important questions, and our happiness depends on their resolution. (8) How to live in order to feel that you are necessary for life, how to live without losing faith and desire, how to live so that not a single second disappears without disturbing the soul and mind? (9) Will the clock, whose movement has no end, ever answer all this - what will the clock say to this? (10) Tick tock, tick tock! (11) There is nothing in the world more dispassionate than a clock: they knock equally correctly at the moment of your birth, and at the time when you greedily pluck the flowers of the dreams of youth. (12) From the day of his birth, every day a person becomes closer to death. (13) And when you wheeze in agony, the clock will calmly and dryly count its seconds. (14) In their cold count - listen - there is something omniscient and tired of this knowledge. (15) Nothing, never excites them and is not dear to them. (16) They are indifferent, and we, if we want to live, need to create for ourselves other hours, full of sensations and thoughts, full of actions, in order to replace these boring, monotonous, melancholy, reproachful and cold-sounding hours. (17) There is no fixed point in the tireless movement of the clock - what do we call real? (18) After one second born, the second is born and pushes the first into the abyss of the unknown ... (19) Tick-tock! - and you are happy. (20) Tick tock! - and now the burning poison of grief pours into your heart, and it can stay with us for the rest of your life, for all the hours of the life given to you, if you do not try to fill every second of your life with something new and alive. (According to M. Gorky).

passage.text: "(1) On another post-concert day, Kozlovsky and I, having separated from the rest of the group, went to the Yuryev Monastery. (2) The once richest Orlova-Chesmenskaya, which in turn was patronized by Archimandrite Photius, flourishing under the golden protective rain, St. , was empty. (3) No fabulous treasures (for example, the icon "Sign" carved on a huge emerald), no monastic rank, no monastic meals, no large litanies, no loud deacons, no bell ringing that spread over Lake Ilmen twenty versts ... (4) Now there was only smooth green grass, and on it a white-stone building. (5) A monastic wall with towers, in the middle a grandiose, the second after Novgorod Sophia, St. George's Cathedral. (6) So the deceased person is still retains for the living, looking at him, features of similarity, and everything seems to have remained the same: nose, chin, and hands, but why should we deceive ourselves, a person is dead and cold, and his external likeness is itself I'm a blatant lie. (7) An elderly woman, rattling keys, opened the St. George's Cathedral to us, and we entered a cold, real space, bounded high above by a painted dome, and to our right with an iconostasis as high as an eight-storey building? (8) The key keeper remained below, but we climbed a narrow spiral staircase to the choir. (9) Probably, they corresponded to the fourth or even the fifth floor, but there was still a lot of height above them: a good half of the iconostasis, against which we stood, and above the iconostasis there is a dome, and above the dome there is an empty drum, one of it would be enough for a small little church. (10) We stood alone in the choir, and there was not a soul or a living spirit in the whole cathedral. (11) The housekeeper was supposed to remain below, but we did not see her, and she did not seem to exist for us. (12) We were each silent about our own, but we must assume that in many places our silence coincided, and the silence of the cathedral contributed to it and even, who knows, directed it in the right direction. (13) And then the silence burst like a pulled string, but only without a tearing string sound, but immediately another live and strong string sounded and instantly filled the entire huge cathedral with sound. (14) A wave of delight splashed in me from heart to eyes and throat. (15) Rachmaninoff's version of the famous chant was taken immediately and with full force. (16) Whether the acoustics of the cathedral contributed to the impression, was it an extraordinary moment itself, an extraordinary emotional mood, but maybe Kozlovsky never sang so beautifully and with inspiration in his life. (17) If it is true that the audience inspires, then what kind of audience was the singer holding now in front of his half-closed eyes? (18) His voice poured golden, dazzling light, and the stones of the cathedral, awakened and revived, resonated to him with every grain of sand. (19) Downstairs, the old woman with the keys was crying and was about to rush at the feet of the singer, but Kozlovsky lifted her up and calmed her down, stroking her shoulder: Nothing, nothing, granny, lock behind us, thank you, we'll go ... (20) Like this life gave me one of its best impressions, of those impressions that lie in the memory as golden seeds and which, generally speaking, accumulate during life not so much. (According to V.A. Soloukhin *) "

passage.text: (1) There is no doubt that humanity will find ways leading to renewal, deepening and fostering of its culture. (9) And so each of us must first of all learn to be grateful. (10) As soon as we open our spiritual eye and take a closer look at life, we will see that every moment, as it were, tests us, whether we are ripe for gratitude and whether we know how to thank. (11) And the one who passes this test turns out to be a man of the future: he is called to create a new world and its culture, he already carries them in himself. (12) He is a creative person; and the one who does not withstand this test is possessed by spiritual blindness and envy, he carries in himself the decomposition of a perishing culture, he is a man of an obsolete past. (13) This is the criterion of spirituality, here is the law and measure, which few people think about, but by which it is necessary to distinguish people. (14) What is gratitude? (15) This is the answer of a living, loving heart to the benefit rendered to it. (17) Gratitude does not need verbal expressions, and sometimes it is better for a person to experience and express it wordlessly. (18) Gratitude is not a simple recognition of someone else's good deed, for an embittered heart accompanies such recognition with a feeling of resentment, humiliation, or even a thirst for revenge. (19) No, real gratitude is joy and love, and in the future - the need to respond with good to good. (20) And the future of humanity belongs precisely to grateful hearts. (According to I. Ilyin)

passage.text: (1)Софья Ивановна была одной из тех редких немолодых женщин, рождённых для семейной жизни, которым судьба отказала в этом счастии и которые вследствие этого отказа весь тот запас любви, который так долго хранился, рос и креп в их сердце для детей и мужа, решаются вдруг изливать на некоторых избранных. (3)Есть три рода любви: любовь красивая, любовь самоотверженная и любовь деятельная. (4)Я говорю про любовь к человеку, которая, смотря по большей или меньшей силе души, сосредоточивается на одном, на некоторых или изливается на многих. (5)Про любовь к матери, к отцу, к брату, к детям, к товарищу, к подруге, к соотечественнику, про любовь к человеку. (6)Любовь красивая заключается в любви к красоте самого чувства и его выражения. (7)Люди, которые любят красивой любовью, очень мало заботятся о взаимности как об обстоятельстве, не имеющем никакого влияния на красоту и приятность чувства. (8)Они часто переменяют предметы своей любви, так как их главная цель состоит только в том, чтоб приятное чувство любви было постоянно возбуждаемо. (9)Для того чтобы поддержать в себе это приятное чувство, они постоянно в самых изящных выражениях говорят о своей любви как самому предмету, так и всем тем, кому даже и нет до этой любви никакого дела. (10)Для людей, которые так любят, любимый предмет любезен настолько, насколько он возбуждает то приятное чувство, сознанием и выражением которого они наслаждаются. (11)Второго рода любовь – любовь самоотверженная, она заключается в любви к процессу жертвования собой для любимого предмета, при этом не обращается внимание на то, хуже или лучше от этих жертв любимому предмету. (12)Люди, любящие так, никогда не верят взаимности. (13)Им всё равно, хорошо ли вы ели, хорошо ли спали, весело ли вам, здоровы ли вы, и они ничего не сделают, чтоб доставить вам эти удобства, ежели они в их власти. (14)Но стать под пулю, броситься в воду, в огонь, зачахнуть от любви – на это они всегда готовы, ежели только встретится случай. (15)Кроме того, люди, склонные к любви самоотверженной, бывают всегда горды своею любовью, взыскательны, ревнивы, недоверчивы и, странно сказать, желают своим предметам опасностей, чтоб избавлять от них, несчастий, чтоб утешать, и даже пороков, чтоб исправлять от них. (16)Третий род – любовь деятельная, она заключается в стремлении удовлетворять все нужды, все желания, прихоти, даже пороки любимого существа. (17)Люди, которые любят так, любят на всю жизнь. (20)Только годы спустя я оценил вполне Софью Ивановну, но и тогда мне пришёл в голову вопрос: почему Дмитрий, старавшийся понимать любовь совершенно иначе, чем обыкновенно молодые люди, и имевший всегда перед глазами милую, любящую Софью Ивановну, вдруг страстно полюбил непонятную Любовь Сергеевну и только допускал, что в его тётке есть тоже хорошие качества.
